Even if motion is important to these moments‚Äìa breeze blowing, leaves falling, or snow drifting downwards‚Äìa single, static image is enough to capture at least the heart of those seasons‚Äô joy.!#@p!#@But spring‚Å†01 ? Spring is something different.!#@p!#@I used to think the problem with these classroom posters was that trees filled with pink flowers aren‚Äôt even realistic, but I‚Äôve learned the last few months that it‚Äôs not a lie. I thought it was just the cherry blossoms, because they‚Äôre all anyone talks about. And sure, there‚Äôs a good reason: cherry blossoms absolutely gorgeous. Trees with dark, delicate branches fully covered in soft pink petals‚Äìit‚Äôs flowers straight through, and they‚Äôre magical.!#@p!#@!#@img[https://mitadmissions.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/20240403_162855-400x533.jpg]!#@The thing is, I thought it was just the cherry blossoms. I thought they were a hyperbolic archetype of pink-flowered trees‚Äìan exaggeration of a spring where some trees might grow a handful of flowers (speckled against a backdrop of green), and most do little more than sprout leaves and continue on their merry way. But it‚Äôs not just the cherry blossoms.!#@p!#@It started when I noticed the massive flowers emerging from a tree near Lobby 7, MIT‚Äôs main entrance to the central academic buildings. There weren‚Äôt a ton of them, and most of them were still tucked into their fuzzy little pods, but it only took them a couple of days to fully emerge.!#@p!#@About a week later, as I walked down dorm row to class, I noticed two trees with some buds emerging as well. They were pale green and fuzzy, large and‚Ä¶ oh. They were definitely the same as the ones near Lobby 7. Except there were a lot more of them.!#@p!#@And then, day by day, the buds started opening up. I could see hints of pink. Then white. Then the petals started separating, and THEY BLOOMED!!!! I‚Äôve never seen this many massive flowers bloom all at once and all in one place. It‚Äôs truly one of the most magical experiences I‚Äôve had in nature‚Äìall these enormous petals gazing up at the sun with dark pink veins reaching up towards the white tips‚Äìand they were right along my daily walk from dorm to classes.!#@p!#@!#@img[https://mitadmissions.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/20240416_124759-800x1067.jpg]!#@!#@img[https://mitadmissions.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/20240416_124817-800x1067.jpg]!#@!#@img[https://mitadmissions.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/20240416_124806-800x1067.jpg]!#@Over the next few weeks, I quickly learned that the magnolia trees are far from the only things blooming on campus in April and May. I guess spring really does live up to the image of flower-covered trees (at least in Boston)! I have more than a hundred photos‚Å†02 in my camera roll of flowers all across campus, so I‚Äôll put a handful below if you‚Äôre curious:!#@p!#@!#@img[https://mitadmissions.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/20240430_125027-800x1067.jpg]!#@!#@img[https://mitadmissions.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/20240510_124853-800x1067.jpg]!#@!#@img[https://mitadmissions.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/20240501_160306-800x1067.jpg]!#@!#@img[https://mitadmissions.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/20240521_1233302-800x1067.jpg]!#@!#@img[https://mitadmissions.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/20240513_1301462-800x1067.jpg]!#@But as beautiful and photogenic as all the flowers are, they‚Äôre not what I loved most about springtime. Certainly not the way that fresh snow is the most powerful moment of winter for me (I LOVE SNOW), or the way that a picture of auburn leaves falling captures the spirit of fall. For me, the defining experience of spring was not the flowers, but watching them grow.!#@p!#@I love walking down dorm row each morning to see the bushes just the slightest bit denser with green, or the daffodil petals spread out just a bit more beneath the sun. Every once in a while, I‚Äôll notice a new color for the first time‚Äìthe vibrant red of a not-quite-tulip(?) emerging from the ground, or tiny specks of green dotting a tree that was once bare. Then there‚Äôs the transitions past spring and towards summer‚Äìwhen the neon green‚Å†03 of freshly-budded leaves darkens to a deeper shade, or the flowers fall petal by petal‚Å†04 in what practically looks like snowfall.!#@p!#@!#@img[https://mitadmissions.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/20240416_125524-800x1067.jpg]!#@!#@img[https://mitadmissions.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/20240501_160418-1-800x1067.jpg]!#@!#@img[https://mitadmissions.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/20240320_165808-1-800x1067.jpg]!#@!#@img[https://mitadmissions.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/20240404_114922-800x1067.jpg]!#@!#@img[https://mitadmissions.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/20240508_1903092-800x1067.jpg]!#@Nature is changing at all times of the year, of course, but it‚Äôs so much easier to notice the little bursts of green appearing on the blank canvas of winter than it is to notice the patches fading to yellow against an already vibrant summer. There‚Äôs also just‚Ä¶ the joy of watching things grow. Seeing the leaves emerge over the course of many days makes me feel like I‚Äôm a part of it all. I like to imagine that I‚Äôm the one turning the clock hands round and round, coaxing the flower buds open and unfurling leaves and slowly darkening the colors of springtime. It‚Äôs a grandiose little delusion‚Å†05 , but a fun one nonetheless!!#@p!#@Because of all this, the defining experience of my first springtime in Boston really has been watching all these slow and incremental changes around me.!#@p!#@Aaand maybe inside me as well, because now that I‚Äôm looking back on my first year at MIT, I‚Äôm realizing how many similarly slow ways I myself have grown.!#@p!#@In the day-to-day chaos of the semester, I always looked to ‚ÄúThings I Did üí™üèº‚Äù as my touchpoints of pride and growth‚Äìcooking a massive meal with friends, helping run an ESP program or Science Olympiad tournament, or traveling alone. But I didn‚Äôt really notice or appreciate the more gradual changes. With scores of new people met and new friends made, I‚Äôve learned how to make conversation more easily. In meeting after meeting with my UROP‚Å†06 supervisor or lab, I‚Äôve learned to speak with confidence about my work. From new club position to new club position, I‚Äôve learned how to navigate new responsibilities (without the crutch of an experienced person directly beside me). I‚Äôve learned how to take notes in lectures, I‚Äôve learned how to shop for groceries (kinda), how to live with roommates, how to work with less sleep, and so much more.!#@p!#@There‚Äôs nothing photogenic about the process of learning how to shop for groceries‚Å†07 , even if the end product is rather nice. But it‚Äôs that slow progression‚Äìthat transition from the tiny bud of a skill to a fully bloomed ability‚Äìthat‚Äôs the experience that‚Äôs been the most fulfilling. And in this case, it‚Äôs not a delusion to imagine that I‚Äôm the one turning the clock hands round to make it all happen :D!#@p!#@P.S. As hard as I tried to capture the joy of watching everything grow with my deluge of photos, there was only one way I could do it a little bit of justice. So‚Ä¶ here‚Äôs forty-five‚Å†08 pictures of the same tree along dorm row from March through May.!#@p!#@
